skills.name: Shade unit fractions when part of a shape
Identify equivalent fractions when presented as shapes or objects
Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers

explanations.A: Not quite, you need to do the same operation to the numerator and denominator
explanations.B: Not quite, you need to do the same operation to the numerator and denominator
explanations.C: Not quite, when finding equivalent fractions we need to use multiplication and division
explanations.D: We have 12/6 = 2, so the scale factor is 2. Multiplying 4 by 2 gives the numerator, 8.

explanations.A: Not quite, you need to do the same operation to the numerator and denominator
explanations.B: Not quite, when finding equivalent fractions we need to use multiplication and division
explanations.C: As the denominator is multiplied by 3, we can multiply the numerator by the same amount to get 6/9.
explanations.D: Not quite, you need to do the same operation to the numerator and denominator

explanations.A: This is how many need to be shaded in the first diagram to make it full. How many little squares do we need to shade so the same amount is shaded as in the first diagram?
explanations.B: We have 3 rectangles in the first shape, but how many small squares would this be in the second shape?
explanations.C: We have three quarters shaded. As the second fraction has 16 parts, we need three quarters of 16 which is 12.
explanations.D: I think you have counted all the unshaded parts. How many little squares do we need to shade so the same amount is shaded as in the first diagram?

explanations.A: The fraction on the left is 2/4 and the fraction on the right is ?/16. As the denominator is multiplied by 4, we can multiply the numerator by 4 to get 8/16.
explanations.B: This is how many parts there are in the second diagram. How many little squares do we need to shade so the same amount is shaded as in the first diagram?
explanations.C: We have 2 rectangles in the first shape, but how many small squares would this be in the second shape?
explanations.D: I think you have counted all the unshaded parts. How many little squares do we need to shade so the same amount is shaded as in the first diagram?

explanations.A: The numerator hasn't been multiplied by 2, so we can't multiply the denominator by 2
explanations.B: Equivalent fractions are different fractions that represent the same value. To make an equivalent fraction, the numerator and denominator must be multiplied by the same number (this keeps the values in proportion). Here, the 2 has been multiplied by 3 to give 6, and so the 7 must also be multiplied by 3, giving an answer of 21.
explanations.C: To find equivalent fractions we need to multiply or divide the numerators and denominators by the same number
explanations.D: Not quite, we need to multiply the denominator by the same amount as the numerator to get the equivalent fraction.

explanations.A: Not quite. The numerator has been multiplied by 6, not 9
explanations.B: To find equivalent fractions we need to multiply or divide the numerators and denominators by the same number
explanations.C: Equivalent fractions are different fractions that represent the same value. To make an equivalent fraction, the numerator and denominator must be multiplied by the same number (this keeps the values in proportion). Here, the 3 has been multiplied by 6 to give 18, and so the 11 must also be multiplied by 6, giving an answer of 66.
explanations.D: Not quite, we need to multiply the denominator by the same amount as the numerator to get the equivalent fraction.

explanations.A: We can only form equivalent fractions by multiplying or dividing both the numerator and denominator by the same number. Tom divided both by 3 to get 3/5 then multiplied both by 4 to give 12/20. These are therefore equivalent. It looks like Katie just added 6 on to both the numerator and denominator, which does not give an equivalent fraction.
explanations.B: Remember you can only make an equivalent fraction by multiplying or dividing both the numerator and denominator by the same number. Not by adding or subtracting.
explanations.C: Remember you can only make an equivalent fraction by multiplying or dividing both the numerator and denominator by the same number. Not by adding or subtracting.
explanations.D: Not quite. Try simplifying the 9/15 first and then see if either Tom or Katie's answer is equivalent.

explanations.A: Not quite! Have you read the whole question? Make sure you check both Jo's and Paul's answers.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try simplifying the 8/14 first and then see if Jo's answer or Paul's answer is equivalent.
explanations.C: We can form equivalent fractions by multiplying or dividing both the numerator and denominator by the same number. Paul multiplied 8 by 5 to get 40 and 14 by 5 to get 70, giving him an equivalent fraction. Jo divided the numerator and denominator by 2 to get 4/7 and then multiplied them both by 3 to get 12/21.
explanations.D: Not quite. Try simplifying the 8/14 first and then see if Jo's answer or Paul's answer is equivalent.

explanations.A: It looks like you have just used the denominator of this fraction. Remember 1/3 means 1 of 3 equal parts. Can you split this shape into 3 equal parts?
explanations.B: Nearly! I think you used the correct method, but counted the squares incorrectly. Count them again carefully.
explanations.C: There are 15 squares in total. 1/3 of the shape means 1 of 3 equal parts. We first need to split the shape into 3 equal parts by dividing 15 by 3. This means there will be 5 squares in each part. We want 1 part so need to shade 5 squares.
explanations.D: It looks like you may have doubled the denominator of this fraction. Remember 1/3 means 1 of 3 equal parts. Can you split this shape into 3 equal parts?

explanations.A: There are 15 squares in total. 1/5 of the shape means 1 of 5 equal parts. We first need to split the shape into 5 equal parts by dividing 15 by 5. This means there will be 3 squares in each part. We want 1 part so need to shade 3 squares.
explanations.B: Remember 1/5 means 1 of 5 equal parts. Can you split this shape into 5 equal parts?
explanations.C: It looks like you have just used the denominator of this fraction. Remember 1/5 means 1 of 5 equal parts. Can you split this shape into 5 equal parts?
explanations.D: You have found the total number of squares, but we need 1/5 of these squares. Remember 1/5 means 1 out of 5 equal parts. Can you split this shape into 5 equal parts?
